subject: Re: [junit] Clarifying how to use unit tests
msgSnippet: Thank you both for your replies. You both completely understood my situation. Yes, I am a top-down design sorta guy. Especially as in most projects I work on
messageBody:
Thank you both for your replies. You both completely understood my
situation.

Yes, I am a top-down design sorta guy. Especially as in most projects I
work on there is very little upfront technical design (no UML,
Requirements specs, etc). Thats why i liked TDD, I could start from the
'front-end' and the design just fell out natuarlly because I was always
thinking about the use of the code.

JB calls it "Story Test-Driven Development". Apart from the obvious Kent
Beck/XP books is their any more info on this?

Thanks again,

Rakesh

J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

>Rakesh Patel wrote:
>
>
>>Hi
>>
>>I don't have much experience with unit testing and JUnit but recently I
>>needed to build my own authentication component for a project i was
>>working on. I decided to try unit testing.
>>
>>So, I started with an obvious class and started to build the methods i
>>thought it needed and the accompanying test class with methods that
>>tested the respective methods of the class under test. As the code base
>>grew I found refactoring quite a burden. Perhaps I had my intial design
>>incorrect.
>>
>>Then i decided to try TDD. Wow! Suddenly i was writing code to satisfy
>>my tests (a client) and things seemed a lot more natural. Productivity
>>increased and i built only what i needed. I think this is how
>>development should happen (I have since hit a wall with testing
>>non-POJOs that I am still grappling with).
>>
>>However, the tests that result from TDD are NOT unti tests. They are
>>actually quite high-level. I found dropping out of TDD into unit testing
>>quite hard and unnatural. Even though the resulting tests are important
>>to have, i couldn't help feeling that by not writing the lower-level
>>unit tests (against say a private method) I was not doing the right thing.
>>
>>Does anyone understand what I mean? Have i misunderstood unit testing
>>and TDD?
>>
>>
>
>It sounds like your TDD tests were more of "integration tests" than of
>"unit tests". I'll guess that you like to take a top-down approach to
>design. If you do, then take care to examine how many different objects
>participate in a test. If it's more than one, then you should consider
>what behavior you need from each object, then test-driving (performing
>TDD on) each object in isolation. When you think you've built the
>behavior you need from each object, you can put them together to pass
>the original integration test you wrote.
>
>This is very close to Story Test-Driven Development, so you haven't
>misunderstood TDD, but rather have noticed that one can practise TDD at
>different levels of the design.
>
>
